title-group.article-title: Twenty-year trends in cardiovascular risk factors in India and influence of educational status

abstract.p: Background: Urban middle-socioeconomic status (SES) subjects have high burden of cardiovascular risk factors in low-income countries. To determine secular trends in risk factors among this population and to correlate risks with educational status we performed epidemiological studies in India.

Methods: Five cross-sectional studies were performed in middle-SES urban locations in Jaipur, India from years 1992 to 2010. Cluster sampling was performed. Subjects (men, women) aged 20–59 years evaluated were 712 (459, 253) in 1992–94, 558 (286, 272) in 1999–2001, 374 (179, 195) in 2002–03, 887 (414, 473) in 2004–05, and 530 (324, 206) in 2009–10. Data were obtained by history, anthropometry, and fasting blood glucose and lipids estimation. Response rates varied from 55 to 75%. Mean values and risk factor prevalence were determined. Secular trends were identified using quadratic and log-linear regression and chi-squared for trend.

Results: Across the studies, there was high prevalence of overweight, hypertension, and lipid abnormalities. Age- and sex-adjusted trends showed significant increases in mean body mass index (BMI), fasting glucose, total cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides (quadratic and log-linear regression, p < 0.001). Systolic blood pressure (BP) decreased while insignificant changes were observed for waist–hip ratio and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol. Categorical trends showed increase in overweight and decrease in smoking (p < 0.05); insignificant changes were observed in truncal obesity, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, and diabetes. Adjustment for educational status attenuated linear trends in BMI and total and LDL cholesterol and accentuated trends in systolic BP, glucose, and HDL cholesterol. There was significant association of an increase in education with decline in smoking and an increase in overweight (two-line regression p < 0.05).

Conclusion: In Indian urban middle-SES subjects there is high prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors. Over a 20-year period BMI and overweight increased, smoking and systolic BP decreased, and truncal obesity, hypercholesterolaemia, and diabetes remained stable. Increasing educational status attenuated trends for systolic BP, glucose and HDL cholesterol, and BMI.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: India has undergone unprecedented social and economic changes in recent years.1 The socioeconomic status (SES) of the population has increased rapidly in the last 20 years, beginning in the early 1990s. This growth has resulted in a substantial increase in the number of middle-SES subjects, the middle class, who typically live in urban locations with modern amenities, such as well-connected road networks, adequate housing in isolated buildings or apartments, uninterrupted power and water supply, stable jobs and incomes, and ownership of cars, scooters, televisions, washing machines, and other labour-saving devices, and have access to manual labour for household chores.2 This situation is similar to the socioeconomic progress in middle of the last century in high-income countries of Europe and North America.3 During this period, in these countries, there was a decline in infection and undernutrition-related diseases and an increase in non-communicable diseases such as cardiovascular diseases (CVD).3 Increased education and SES, better risk factor awareness, and greater risk factor control has resulted in decline in cardiovascular risk factors4,5 and reduced CVD morbidity and mortality in many high-income countries.36–8

CVD has emerged as a major killer in India, more in urban locations. The prevalence of CVD, as well as risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidaemias, is 2–5 times greater in urban locations as compared to rural locations and appears to be increasing.9 Secular trends in cardiovascular risk factors have not been well studied in India. It has been reported that urban middle-SES subjects have a high burden of cardiovascular risk.10–12 This SES group is most exposed to influences of rapid urbanization and socioeconomic change which are important determinants of risk.13 This group is also the most socially malleable and it changes lifestyle quickly with emerging health-related information.2,13 To determine secular trends in cardiovascular risk factors in urban middle-SES subjects, as determined by the location of residence,14 and to evaluate importance of educational status, as proxy for health literacy,14 we performed cross-sectional epidemiological studies.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p:
We performed a series of cross-sectional epidemiological studies in Jaipur in north-western India (Jaipur Heart Watch, JHW) over the past 20 years to determine cardiovascular risk factors in urban subjects.15–19 All the studies were approved by institutional ethics committees and supported financially by different organizations. The first study (JHW-1)15 was conducted in years 1992–1994. This study was designed to investigate people at random and to cover large and varied areas of this city with the intention of including a wide range of urban subjects. Jaipur is divided into 70 municipal wards. Randomly chosen wards from different regions of the city were identified to cover different SES groups. We studied people in middle-class locations of Jawahar Nagar, Janta Colony, Raja Park, and Jaipur South and low middle-class colonies of Ramganj Bazar, Chandpole Bazar, and Moti Doongri Road. Details of adult populations in those wards were available from the voters’ lists. These lists give the names of all individuals aged 18 years or more. The total adult population in each ward varied from 15,000–30,000. The male/female ratio of Jaipur residents >20 years old is 1000 : 865. We randomly selected 500 persons (268 men, 232 women) from each locality from the list of voters. When the random number corresponded to the individual <20 years of age, it was assigned to the next person on the list. The target study sample was 3000 with a population-proportionate male/female ratio, thus 1609 men and 1391 women were invited to participate. The formula for calculation of sample size is based on World Health Organization (WHO) recommendations16 and reported earlier.15 The study was preceded by meeting with local leaders who cooperated in identifying and ensuring participation of selected subjects. Interviews and examinations were performed at a public place (school, temple, mosque, etc. within the municipal ward).15 A total of 2212 subjects (response 73.7%, men 1415, women 797) were evaluated for cardiovascular risk factors. Measurement of waist–hip ratio (WHR) and fasting blood sample were performed in 15% of participants and, as this number was low in middle-SES locations, these data were not included in the present study. In the second urban study (JHW-2),17 we targeted 950 men and 850 women in the same locations as in JHW-1 and could examine 1123 subjects (62.4%, men 550, women 573). In this study, we targeted all the participants for the fasting blood sample. For the present study, we have included subjects residing in middle-SES locations (Table 1).The third (JHW-3),18 fourth (JHW-4),19 and fifth (JHW-5)20 urban studies were middle-SES location-specific targeted at a smaller sample in the three middle-SES municipal wards. These numbers were derived using WHO guidelines to estimate differences in risk factor prevalence.21 The required sample size for recognizing a 2-point difference in mean values with standard deviation of 10.0 and the study power at 85% and significance at 5% (two-tailed test) is 450.21 We analysed data among middle-aged subjects 20–59 years living in the same middle-SES locations (Jawahar Nagar, Janata Colony, Raja Park) in various cohorts (Table 1). Middle-SES locations were defined according to the Jaipur Municipal Council classification.22 This is based on the cost of land, type of housing, public facilities (proper roads, water, electricity, and gas supply), educational and medical facilities and municipal taxes. Each of the municipal ward has a population of about 15,000–30,000 adults and thus sampling was from a total population of about 60,000 adults according to government voters’ lists. Table 1.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Methodological details have been reported previously.15 A detailed proforma was utilized for data collection. Briefly, we collected information regarding demographic data, history of major illnesses such as coronary heart disease, hypertension, diabetes, or high cholesterol levels, and smoking or tobacco intake. Brief questions were asked to evaluate physical activity and diet but the results were considered inadequate and not included in the analyses. Physical examination was performed to assess height, weight, waist and hip size, and blood pressure (BP) using previously reported methodology.15 BP was measured in the sitting position using calibrated mercury instruments. Three readings were obtained at 5-min intervals and the lowest value retained.15,17 Body mass index (BMI) was calculated as weight (kg) divided by squared height (m2). WHR was calculated. Fasting glucose was determined at a central laboratory using glucose peroxidase method and external quality control. Quality control measures were also followed for the estimation of total cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides while low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol was estimated using the Friedewald formula. Internal and external quality control was maintained in all the studies to ensure uniformity of methodology.23

sec.title: Diagnostic criteria
sec.p: All present and past smokers and users of non-smoked tobacco have been included in smoker category. The diagnostic criteria for tobacco use as well as other coronary risk factors have been advised by WHO.16,21 Hypertension was diagnosed when systolic BP was ≥140 mmHg and/or diastolic BP ≥90 mmHg or a person was a known hypertensive. Overweight or obesity was defined as BMI ≥25 kg/m2.24 Truncal obesity was diagnosed when WHR was >0.95 in males and >0.85 in females according to the US National Cholesterol Education Program (NCEP) guidelines.25 Dyslipidaemia was defined by the presence of high total cholesterol (≥200 mg/dl), high LDL cholesterol (≥100 mg/dl), low HDL cholesterol (<40 mg/dl in men and <50 mg/dl in women), or high triglycerides (≥150 mg/dl) according to NCEP guidelines.25 Diabetes was diagnosed on the basis of either history of known diabetes or fasting glucose ≥126 mg/dl.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: The continuous variables are reported as mean ± SD and ordinal variables as percentage. Normality in distribution of continuous variables was determined. Age-stratified values of various numeric variables are reported and age-adjustment was performed within the statistical package (SPSS version 16.0; SPSS, Chicago, USA) using analysis of covariance. To determine trends in numerical risk factors, regression analyses were performed using the curvefit command within the statistical package. The most significant R2 values were obtained with quadratic regression; hence, this method was used for identification of trends. Log-linear regression was also performed to identify trends as it leads to smoothing of the quadratic graphs. Multivariate regression was performed after adjustment for age (decadal groups), gender, and educational status (groups). Prevalence rates are reported as percentage. Age-stratified prevalence rates and distribution of various risk factors were determined for decadal intervals from 20 years to 59 years and age-adjustment of various prevalence rates was performed by direct method using the standard million Indian population of year 1971.26 Significance of trends in prevalence rates was determined using Mantel–Haenszel chi-squared for trend. To evaluate influence of changing educational status on various categorical risk factor trends, we performed two-line regression analyses using GB-Stat Version 7 (Dynamic Microsystems, Silver Springs Maryland, USA). Two-tailed p-values <0.05 were considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
There is an age-associated increase in most of the risk factors. The mean levels of risk factors were not significantly different in men and women (data not shown); hence, we performed a combined analyses. Age- and sex-adjusted mean levels of risk factors in the serial studies show increasing levels of BMI, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides, no significant change in WHR and total cholesterol, and a decline in systolic BP compared to the first study (Table 2, Figure 1). Prevalence of risk factors is shown in Table 3. Prevalence of smoking was high in the first study and low in the subsequent studies. Across the studies, a high prevalence of cardiometabolic risk factors, such as overweight/obesity (BMI ≥25 kg/m2), truncal obesity (WHR >0.95 men, >0.85 women), hypertension, diabetes, and various dyslipidaemias, is observed. sec.title: Trends in risk factors
sec.p:
Age- and sex-adjusted multivariate regression analyses were performed to identify secular trends across various studies (Table 4). Curvefit analysis demonstrated that R2 values were highest with quadratic regression (Table 4), hence, this was used as principal method of analysis. Log-linear trends were also calculated (Table 4). Significantly increasing quadratic as well as log-linear trends were observed for BMI, fasting glucose, total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides (p < 0.001). Significantly declining trends were observed for systolic BP (p < 0.0001), while insignificant changes were observed for WHR and LDL cholesterol (Table 4). Figure 3.

Quadratic regression (red line) shows significant curvilinear trends for body mass index, systolic BP, glucose fasting, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides (p < 0.001). Log-linear (green) and linear (blue) regression trends show significant increase in body mass index, fasting glucose, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides and decline in systolic BP (p < 0.001). Age-adjusted prevalence rates (Table 3) for categorical risk factors showed increasing trends (Mantel Haenszel chi-squared) for overweight/obesity and hypertriglyceridaemia (p < 0.001); borderline significant trends for truncal obesity, hypercholesterolaemia, and diabetes; insignificant changes for hypertension and high LDL cholesterol; and significant declines for prevalence of smoking and low HDL cholesterol.

sec.title: Influence of educational status
sec.p:
There was an increasing trend in post-primary school educational status (>10 years of formal education) in serial JHW studies. It was 39.9% in the first study and 72.0, 74.3, 67.2, and 82.0% in second to fifth studies, respectively. Age- and sex-adjusted linear regression showed significant increases in mean BMI, glucose, total and HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides and a decline in systolic BP (Figure 2, solid lines). Adjustment for educational status led to attenuation of trends for BMI and total cholesterol and accentuation of trends for systolic BP, glucose, and HDL cholesterol (Figure 2, dotted lines). Figure 2.
Linear regression and influence of educational status on risk factors in Jaipur Heart Watch (JHW) surveys. There are significantly increasing trends in body mass index total cholesterol, glucose fasting, triglycerides, and HDL cholesterol and decline in systolic BP (solid line). There is attenuation of correlation after adjustment for education (dotted line) in body mass index and accentuation for systolic BP, fasting glucose, and HDL cholesterol with insignificant change in total cholesterol and triglycerides.

Trends in increasing educational status were correlated with prevalent CVD risk factors comparing the two regression lines with two-line regression analysis. Significant correlations were observed with declining smoking (R2 = 0.92, p = 0.010) and borderline significant trends with increasing overweight (R2 = 0.73, p = 0.067) and hypercholesterolaemia (R2 = 0.70, p = 0.076). The relationship of increasing educational status with other risk factors was insignificant (hypertension R2 = 0.02, truncal obesity R2 = 0.18, and diabetes R2 = 0.22).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study shows a high prevalence of multiple cardiovascular risk factors, overweight and obesity, hypertension, lipid abnormalities, and diabetes, over a 20-year period in Indian middle-SES location-based subjects. This is more than previous population-based studies from India9 and other low-income countries.27 Trend analysis shows increasing mean BMI, fasting glucose, cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides. Categorical analyses show that prevalence of overweight and obesity has increased; truncal obesity, hypertension, lipid abnormalities, and diabetes have remained stable; and smoking has declined. Educational status has increased over this period and is significantly associated with decline in smoking and systolic BP and marginally associated with increasing BMI and hypercholesterolaemia.

Population-level trends in cardiovascular risk factors have been previously studied in high- and middle-income countries of Europe, North America, and Asia-Pacific.28–36 Two types of methodologies are available: long-term cohort studies and serial cross-sectional studies.16 Cohort studies, such as Framingham Heart Study,28 have provided useful data on risk factor trends and their causes but are intensive, time-consuming, and expensive and could be difficult in low-income countries such as India where no formal population identification and tracking system exists. Except Framingham, which showed increasing trends in risk factors till 1960s,37 other observational studies, such as Lipid Research Clinics Prevalence Mortality Study, placebo arms of Coronary Primary Prevention trial, and Multiple Risk Factor Intervention trial,38 and population-based observational studies, such as Minnesota Heart Survey,39 demonstrated a persistent decline in risk factors, beginning in the 1960s. Longitudinal cohort studies from other parts of the world (mainly Western Europe and Asia-Pacific region) have reported similar trends.29–32 The present study is not a cohort and we therefore cannot compare our results.

Serial cross-sectional epidemiological studies in other parts of the world have provided information on trends in cardiovascular risk factors. Seven Countries Study in Europe, North America, and Asia,40 MONICA (Monitoring of Cardiovascular Diseases) led by WHO in different parts of the world,41 US National Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys (NHANES),42 and many similar studies in Europe, Latin America, and Southeast Asia have provided useful data on risk factor trends.43–47 These studies are simpler and less expensive and provide useful data. These studies reported that cardiovascular risk factors followed a certain trend in high-income countries.6 In the 1950s and 1960s, there was an increase in risk factors such as smoking, hypertension, and lipid abnormalities. From the 1970s onwards, there has been a continuing decline in prevalence of smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolaemia.34 The 1990s saw an increase in BMI and obesity in most high-income countries and an increasing prevalence of metabolic syndrome and diabetes.48 Studies from middle-income countries in the Americas, Europe, and southeast Asia have reported increasing hypertension and metabolic risk factors from the 1970s to the 1990s, with subsequent stabilization and decline.45–47,49 The Global Burden of Metabolic Risk Factors of Chronic Diseases Collaboration reported international trends in BMI, BP, and cholesterol levels collating cross-sectional data from more than 190 countries and millions of subjects over a 35-year period.50–52 There was a significant heterogeneity in trends in risk factors across the globe.5 Mean BMI increased in all parts of the world (high-, middle-, and low-income countries) but the increase was steepest in middle-income countries and least in low-income countries.50 Mean systolic BP declined sharply in high-income countries, declined marginally in middle-income countries, and increased significantly in low-income countries.51 Mean cholesterol levels declined in high-income countries but remained almost stable in low-income countries.52 The present study shows increasing quadratic trends in BMI (+0.99 ± 0.10 kg/m2/study), declining systolic BP (−1.48 ± 0.34 mmHg), and increasing cholesterol levels (+3.37 ± 2.13 mg/dl) (Table 4). These results are similar to those observed in middle-income countries5 and indicate a significant SES-based heterogeneity in risk factor trends in large countries such as India.

There are limited population-wide studies available from low-income countries that have evaluated cardiovascular risk factor trends,53–55 and none have reported trends using a uniform methodology. The present study is localized to a single urban Indian location using a serial population-based cross-sectional approach and shows that the prevalence of smoking is declining, hypertension is stable, and lipid abnormalities are increasing. This finding is similar to the early phase of disease transition in high-income countries that occurred in early 1970s in USA and Western Europe.56 In India, a study in Chandigarh (North India) reported greater hypertension in urban middle class over a 30-year period57 and a study in Chennai (South India)58 reported an increasing diabetes prevalence over a 15-year period. A hospital-based study in north India reported increasing risk factors and their awareness among middle-class business executives.59

Comparison of the present results with trends in risk factors in NHANES provides useful insights.42,60 This study reported a high prevalence of multiple cardiovascular risk factors in the 1960s. Smoking, hypercholesterolaemia, and hypertension started to decline by the second and third studies in the 1980s and 1990s and the declining trends accelerated in the NHANES-4 by the early 2000s. These trends are ascribed to lifestyle changes and early diagnosis and aggressive management of risk factors.5 On the other hand, cardiometabolic risk factors such as obesity and metabolic syndrome increased in the NHANES populations.48 In the present study we observed declining smoking, unchanged hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, and diabetes, and increasing obesity. These trends are similar to the earlier NHANES60 studies and could be due to lifestyle changes and better disease management.5

An important finding of the present study is the relationship of risk factor trends with educational level of the subjects. The relationship of multiple socioeconomic factors involved in the disease epidemiological transition from communicable to non-communicable diseases and the rise and fall of cardiovascular diseases has been studied previously.8,13,14 These societal factors include social organization and urbanization, social gradient, unemployment, work environment, transport, social support and cohesion, food, poverty and social exclusion, and individual health behaviours.61 Education is a marker of many of these and is the most frequently used in cardiovascular epidemiology.14 As these societal factors increase, there is initially an increase in prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors but as society evolves further there is a decline.11 The REACH Registry investigators observed a complex relationship between educational status, risk factors, and cardiovascular outcomes.62 The study reported that in high-income countries there was an inverse association of educational status with cardiovascular risk factors and outcomes, while in the low- and middle-income countries the relationship was uneven. Some risk factors such as smoking were more with low-educational status while obesity, hypercholesterolaemia, and diabetes were more in the better educated. The present study shows that better education decreases smoking and stabilizes many cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension, hyperglycaemia, and hypercholesterolaemia, despite increasing BMI and obesity. This is similar to the Global Burden of Metabolic Risk Factors reports.5 In a previous study we reported different rates of increase of cardiovascular risk factors in Indian urban subjects.63 While the risk factors (smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolaemia) rapidly increased in low-educational-status subjects, the rate of increase was slow among the better educated. This is similar to studies from China where the risk factors rapidly increased among the low-SES subjects and were static among the upper- and middle-SES subjects over a 7-year period.64 Increasing awareness and treatment of various risk factors is known to lead to decline in risk factors. For example, Copenhagen City Heart Study reported a decline in population BP over a 25-year period, which was ascribed to increasing treatment and control status.65 In the earlier JHW studies we reported an increasing awareness of hypertension.63 Increasing medication use for control of risk factors also leads to a decline in mean values, as reported in a British study.66 We have not evaluated treatment status and cannot comment on its significance. There is an increasing trend in HDL cholesterol in the present study. Regression analysis shows that while increase in total cholesterol is 3.37 ± 2.13 mg/study, that of HDL cholesterol is 3.05 ± 0.47 mg/study (Table 4). We cannot comment on its significance, but such observations are known to occur with rapidly increasing dietary saturated-fat intake. Increase in HDL cholesterol precedes that of total cholesterol.67

Like all cross-sectional studies, our observations have limitations. The results of the study cannot be generalized to the whole country. However, as the human development index of Jaipur is similar to the Indian national average,12 the results can be transposed to the urban population. Moreover, the aim of the present study was to evaluate risk factors in subjects residing in urban middle-class locations and for this reason it fulfils the objective. According to recent estimates, the Indian middle class is more than 300 million strong2 and the results reflect changes in risk factors in this population, which is more than the populations of most countries. Secondly, we classified middle-class locations based on neighbourhood characteristics. Multiple methods exist to classify SES14 and we used a more inclusive method, although in a middle-class neighbourhood there could be some upper- and lower-SES groups also. Many studies have used this form of classification and it is a well-validated instrument in cardiovascular epidemiology.13,68 Thirdly, the response rates in studies have varied from 55 to 75% which is low but similar to epidemiological studies in other parts of the world and considered adequate by WHO.21 However, small sample size in individual JHW studies is a major study limitation. Fourthly, there is a known gender-related variation in risk factors.50–52 We evaluated gender-related differences in risk factors and found that male/female differences were not significant (data not shown). Moreover, we have adjusted the data for gender in all the calculations. Fifthly, although there are a number of methods to identify trends in risk factors,69 we used quadratic regression as the R2 values were the highest with this method (Table 4). Log-linear regression was performed to smoothen the quadratic curves (Figure 3). To evaluate trends in cardiovascular risk factors, the Global Burden of Metabolic Risk Factors of Chronic Diseases Collaboration50 used a combination of linear and smoothened non-linear trends with complex hierarchal modelling. A much larger sample size is required for calculation of trends with these methods. Sixthly, trends in categorical risk factors (Table 3) could be influenced by large differences in the first and second survey in risk factors such as smoking, overweight/obesity, and hypertension. These larger differences could reflect greater time difference between the first and second survey (7 years) than the subsequent (2–3 years). Census data from the Indian state of Rajasthan also shows a rapid increase in educational status during these years70 and our results could be its reflection. Seventhly, we have not studied diet and physical activity, which are very important lifestyle factors influencing obesity, dyslipidaemias, and other risk factors.71 However, BMI is a summation of physical activity and dietary calories and shows a strong trend. And finally, we have not inquired regarding drug therapies and cannot comment on influence of drug usage on BP and lipid levels. Strengths of the study include length of the study (this is the longest ongoing cardiovascular epidemiological study in India), use of uniform methodology and quality control, and inclusion of urban subjects (who are most prone to the ongoing cardiovascular epidemic).

In conclusion, this study shows a high prevalence of multiple cardiovascular risk factors in Indian urban middle-SES location-based population. It also shows a mixed pattern of 20-year trends in risk factors. While prevalence of smoking has declined and hypertension has stabilized, that of cardiometabolic factors is increasing. The study also shows that educational status is significantly associated with these trends, that the process of disease transition has started in the Indian middle class, and that a decline fuelled by socioeconomic changes and increasing education is inevitable in this group. Whether similar trends occur in other SES groups needs further studies. Meanwhile, a focus on improving general and health literacy, as well as multiple policies and clinical initiatives,72 is urgently needed to curb the cardiovascular epidemic in India and other low-income countries.
